member.name: T:Spring.Stereotype.ComponentAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that an annotated class is a "component". Such classes are considered as candidates for future features such as auto-detection when using attribute-based configuration and assembly scanning.
member.remarks: Other class-level annotations may be considered as identifying a component as well, typically a special kind of component: e.g. the Repository attribute.
member.author: Mark Fisher
Mark Pollack (.NET)

member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the component
member.value: The name of the component.

member.name: T:Spring.Stereotype.RepositoryAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that an annotated class is a "Repository" (or "DAO").
member.remarks:
A class with this attribute is eligible for Spring DataAccessException translation. A class with the Repository attribute is also clarified as to its role in the overall application architecture for the purpose of tools, aspects, etc.
This attribute also serves as a specialization of the ComponentAttribute, allowing implementation classes to be autodetected in future releases through assembly scanning.
member.author: Rod Johnson
Jueren Hoeller
Mark Pollack (.NET)

member.param: The name of the repository.

member.summary: Indicates that an annotated class is a "Service" (e.g. a business service facade).

remarks.para: This attribute also serves as a specialization of the ComponentAttribute, allowing implementation classes to be autodetected in future releases through assembly scanning.

member.name: T:Spring.Threading.ISync
member.summary: Acquire/Release protocol, base of many concurrency utilities.

remarks.p: objects isolate waiting and notification for particular logical states, resource availability, events, and the like that are shared across multiple threads.

Use of s sometimes (but by no means always) adds flexibility and efficiency compared to the use of plain .Net monitor methods and locking, and are sometimes (but by no means always) simpler to program with.
Used for implementation of a

member.author: Doug Lea
Federico Spinazzi (.Net)

member.name: M:Spring.Threading.ISync.Acquire
member.summary: Wait (possibly forever) until successful passage. Fail only upon interuption. Interruptions always result in `clean' failures. On failure, you can be sure that it has not been acquired, and that no corresponding release should be performed. Conversely, a normal return guarantees that the acquire was successful.

member.name: M:Spring.Threading.ISync.Release
member.summary:
Potentially enable others to pass.
Because release does not raise exceptions, it can be used in `finally' clauses without requiring extra embedded try/catch blocks. But keep in mind that as with any java method, implementations may still throw unchecked exceptions such as Error or NullPointerException when faced with uncontinuable errors. However, these should normally only be caught by higher-level error handlers.

member.name: M:Spring.Threading.ISync.Attempt(System.Int64)
member.summary:
Wait at most msecs to pass; report whether passed.
The method has best-effort semantics: The msecs bound cannot be guaranteed to be a precise upper bound on wait time in Java. Implementations generally can only attempt to return as soon as possible after the specified bound. Also, timers in Java do not stop during garbage collection, so timeouts can occur just because a GC intervened. So, msecs arguments should be used in a coarse-grained manner. Further, implementations cannot always guarantee that this method will return at all without blocking indefinitely when used in unintended ways. For example, deadlocks may be encountered when called in an unintended context.
member.param: the number of milleseconds to wait An argument less than or equal to zero means not to wait at all. However, this may still require access to a synchronization lock, which can impose unbounded delay if there is a lot of contention among threads.
member.returns: true if acquired

member.name: T:Spring.Threading.Semaphore

summary.p: Base class for counting semaphores based on Semaphore implementation from Doug Lea.

member.remarks:
Conceptually, a semaphore maintains a set of permits. Each acquire() blocks if necessary until a permit is available, and then takes it.
Each release adds a permit. However, no actual permit objects are used; the Semaphore just keeps a count of the number available and acts accordingly.
A semaphore initialized to 1 can serve as a mutual exclusion lock.
Used for implementation of a
member.author: Doug Lea
Federico Spinazzi (.Net)

member.name: F:Spring.Threading.Semaphore.nPermits
member.summary: current number of available permits

summary.p: Create a Semaphore with the given initial number of permits.
Using a seed of 1 makes the semaphore act as a mutual exclusion lock.
Negative seeds are also allowed, in which case no acquires will proceed until the number of releases has pushed the number of permits past 0.

member.name: T:Spring.Threading.Utils
member.summary: Support to account for differences between java nad .NET:

member.name: M:Spring.Threading.Utils.FailFastIfInterrupted
member.summary:
.NET threads have not a method to check if they have been interrupted. Moreover, differently from java threads, when entering locked blocks, Monitor, Sleep, SpinWait and so on, a will be raised by the runtime.
Spring.Threading classes usually call this method before entering a lock block, to mirror java code
Usually this is non issue because the same exception will be raised entering the monitor associated with the lock ()
member.exception: if the thread has been interrupted

member.name: T:Spring.Util.DynamicCodeManager
member.summary: Use this class for obtaining instances for dynamic code generation.

remarks.p: The purpose of this class is to provide a simple abstraction for creating and managing dynamic assemblies.
remarks.note: Using this factory you can't define several modules within a single dynamic assembly - only a simple one2one relation between assembly/module is used.

example.p: The following excerpt from demonstrates usage:

member.author: Erich Eichinger

member.name: M:Spring.Util.DynamicCodeManager.#ctor
member.summary: prevent instantiation

member.name: M:Spring.Util.DynamicCodeManager.GetModuleBuilder(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the for the dynamic module within the specified assembly.
member.remarks:
If the assembly does not exist yet, it will be created.
This factory caches any dynamic assembly it creates - calling GetModule() twice with the same name will *not* create 2 distinct modules!
member.param: The assembly-name of the module to be returned
member.returns: the that can be used to define new types within the specified assembly

member.summary: Persists the specified dynamic assembly to the file-system

member.remarks: Can only be called in DEBUG_DYNAMIC mode, per ConditionalAttribute rules.

member.name: M:Spring.Util.ObjectUtils.IsAssignableAndNotTransparentProxy(System.Type,System.Object)
member.summary: Checks whether the supplied is not a transparent proxy and is assignable to the supplied .

remarks.p: Neccessary when dealing with server-activated remote objects, because the object is of the type TransparentProxy and regular is testing for assignable types does not work.
Transparent proxy instances always return when tested with the 'is' operator (C#). This method only checks if the object is assignable to the type if it is not a transparent proxy.

member.param: The target to be checked.
The value that should be assigned to the type.
member.returns: if the supplied is not a transparent proxy and is assignable to the supplied .

member.summary: Determine if the given is assignable from the given value, assuming setting by reflection.

remarks.p: Considers primitive wrapper classes as assignable to the corresponding primitive types.
For example used in an object factory's constructor resolution.

member.param: The target .
The value that should be assigned to the type.
member.returns: True if the type is assignable from the value.

member.name: T:Spring.Util.Properties
member.summary: An implementation of the Java Properties class.
member.remarks:
For the complete syntax see java.util.Properties JavaDoc. This class supports an extended syntax. There may also be sole keys on a line, in that case values are treated as null.
key1 = value key2: key3
will result in the name/value pairs:
key1:="value"
key2:=string.Empty
key3:=<null>
note, that to specify a null value, the key must not be followed by any character except newline.
member.author: Simon White

member.name: M:Spring.Util.ReflectionUtils.MemberwiseCopy(System.Object,System.Object)
member.summary: Copies all fields from one object to another.
member.remarks:
The types of both objects must be related. This means, that either of the following is true:
fromObject.GetType() == toObject.GetType()
fromObject.GetType() is derived from toObject.GetType()
toObject.GetType() is derived from fromObject.GetType()
member.param: The source object
The object, who's fields will be populated with values from the source object
member.exception: If the object's types are not related

member.name: M:Spring.Util.StringUtils.HasText(System.String)
member.summary: Checks if a has text.

remarks.p: More specifically, returns if the string is not , it's is > zero (0), and it has at least one non-whitespace character.

member.param: The string to check, may be .
member.returns: if the is not , > zero (0), and does not consist solely of whitespace.

example.code: StringUtils.HasText(null) = false StringUtils.HasText("") = false StringUtils.HasText(" ") = false StringUtils.HasText("12345") = true StringUtils.HasText(" 12345 ") = true

member.name: M:Spring.Util.StringUtils.IsNullOrEmpty(System.String)
member.summary: Checks if a is or an empty string.

remarks.p: More specifically, returns if the string is , it's is equal to zero (0), or it is composed entirely of whitespace characters.

member.param: The string to check, may (obviously) be .
member.returns: if the is , has a length equal to zero (0), or is composed entirely of whitespace characters.

example.code: StringUtils.IsNullOrEmpty(null) = true StringUtils.IsNullOrEmpty("") = true StringUtils.IsNullOrEmpty(" ") = true StringUtils.IsNullOrEmpty("12345") = false StringUtils.IsNullOrEmpty(" 12345 ") = false

member.name: T:Spring.Validation.BaseValidator
member.summary: Base class that defines common properties for all validators.

remarks.p: Custom validators should always extend this class instead of simply implementing interface, in order to inherit common validator functionality.

member.author: Aleksandar Seovic

member.name: T:Spring.Validation.IValidator
member.summary: An object that can validate application-specific objects.

remarks.p: The primary motivation for this interface is to enable validation to be decoupled from the (user) interface and placed in business objects.

Application developers writing their own custom implementations will typically not implement this interface directly. In most cases, custom validators woud be better served deriving from the class, with the custom validation ligic being implemented in an override of the
template method.

member.summary: ISBN-10 consists of 4 groups of numbers separated by either dashes (-) or spaces.

member.name: F:Spring.Validation.Validators.ISBNValidator.ISBN13_PATTERN
member.summary: ISBN-13 consists of 5 groups of numbers separated by either dashes (-) or spaces.
member.remarks: The first group is 978 or 979, the second group is 1-5 characters, third 1-7, fourth 1-6, and fifth is 1 digit.

member.name: T:Spring.Validation.RequiredValidator
member.summary: Validates that required value is not empty.

remarks.p:
This validator uses following rules to determine if target value is valid:
Target Valid Value
A . Not or an empty string.
A . Not and not .
One of the number types. Not zero.
A . Not or whitespace.
Any reference type other than . Not .
You cannot use this validator to validate any value types other than the ones specified in the table above.

member.name: T:Spring.Validation.AnyValidatorGroup
member.summary: implementation that supports grouping of validators.

remarks.p: This validator will be valid when one or more of the validators in the Validators collection are valid.

ValidationErrors property will return a union of all validation error messages for the contained validators, but only if this validator is not valid (meaning, when none of the contained validators are valid).

member.name: T:Spring.Validation.CollectionValidator
member.summary: implementation that supports validating collections.

remarks.p: This validator will be valid only when all of the validators in the Validators collection are valid for all of the objects in the specified collection.
You can specify if you want to validate all of the collection elements regardless of the errors, by setting the ValidateAll property to true.

If you set the IncludeElementErrors property to true, ValidationErrors collection will contain a union of all validation error messages for the contained validators; Otherwise it will contain only error messages that were set for this Validator.

member.author: Damjan Tomic
Aleksandar Seovic

member.name: T:Spring.Validation.ExclusiveValidatorGroup
member.summary: implementation that supports grouping of validators.

remarks.p: This validator will be valid when one and only one of the validators in the Validators collection are valid

ValidationErrors property will return a union of all validation error messages for the contained validators, but only if this validator is not valid (meaning, when none of the contained validators are valid).
By default, this validator group uses == true semantics.

member.author: Aleksandar Seovic

member.name: T:Spring.Validation.ValidatorReference
member.summary: Represents a reference to an externally defined validator object

remarks.p: This class allows validation groups to reference validators that are defined outside of the group itself.
It also allows users to narrow the context for the referenced validator by specifying value for the Context property.
